Content: Happy New Year! While 2020 is behind us, COVID-19 is not. With vaccines being administered across the state, we are making progress, but there is much work left to do. Remember to do your part by wearing your masks, maintaining social distance and washing your hands.

Your best protection from COVID-19 will be a combination of getting a COVID-19 vaccine, wearing a mask, staying at least 6 feet away from others, avoiding crowds, and washing your hands often. No one tool alone is going to stop the pandemic.
And while it‚Äôs safer to be outside or in a well-ventilated space, COVID-19 can still spread in those environments. Wear a mask, wash your hands and watch your distance.

Shop safely this holiday season. Support local businesses by shopping online, using curbside pickup or shopping during non-peak hours at stores. Wear a mask, social distance and wash your hands often if you do go out. For more  holiday guidance, go to:

Remember to wash your hands frequently when cooking and before you eat your meal. Washing your hands often is important for preventing the spread of COVID-19, in addition to wearing masks and social distancing.

Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. 

ü¶†Germs that cause illnesses such as COVID-19, colds, flu, and gastroenteritis can enter your body when your unwashed hands touch your face. Use alcohol-based hand sanitiser when you don‚Äôt have access to soap and water.

COVID-19 is easily spread via tiny air droplets from sneezing and coughing.ü§ßüí¶ Smaller droplets can travel up to 8Ô∏è‚É£ metres.  by sneezing and coughing into a tissue or the inside of your arm. If you use a tissue, wash your hands or use sanitiser after.

Reminder: Avoid touching your face if you haven‚Äôt washed your hands first. When you touch your face with dirty hands, germs can enter your body through your eyes, nose and mouth, and make you unwell.

A study by the  found only 76% of men always wash their hands after going to the toilet, and 59% wash their hands before touching food. Washing your hands regularly can help to reduce your risk of getting sick or passing infections on to others.

Covering your coughs and sneezes in a tissue or your elbow helps to stop the spread of viruses. If you use a tissue, put it in the bin and wash your hands after. Turn away from other people when you cough or sneeze too.

Beware of alcohol-based hand sanitizers packaged in containers that may appear as food or drinks. Hand sanitizer can be toxic if ingested. FDA found hand sanitizers packaged in beer cans; children‚Äôs food pouches; and water, juice and vodka bottles.
Drinking only a small amount of hand sanitizer is potentially lethal to a young child, who may be attracted by a pleasant smell or brightly colored bottle. Learn more on safe use of hand sanitizer:

A consumer reported buying a bottle they thought to be drinking water but was in fact hand sanitizer. Another reported a hand sanitizer product marketed with cartoons for children in a pouch that resembles a snack.

FDA has found that some hand sanitizers are being packaged in beer cans, children‚Äôs food pouches, water bottles, juice bottles ; vodka bottles. Some even contain food flavors, such as chocolate or raspberry. Hand sanitizer can be toxic when ingested.
Beware of alcohol-based hand sanitizers packaged in containers that may appear as food or drinks. These products may put you and your family at risk of serious injury, or death, if ingested.

Is your hand sanitizer on FDA‚Äôs list of products you should not use? Our testing uncovered that some hand sanitizers carry toxic ingredients. An FDA Consumer Update provides information to find out if your product is on the list.

Before you buy hand sanitizer or use hand sanitizer you have at home, check our list. No consumer hand sanitizer is FDA-approved, so that claim on any consumer hand sanitizer product is not trustworthy.

ü¶†Germs that cause illnesses such as COVID-19, colds, flu, and gastroenteritis can enter your body when your unwashed hands touch your face. Use alcohol-based hand sanitiser when you don‚Äôt have access to soap and water.

COVID-19 is easily spread via tiny air droplets from sneezing and coughing.ü§ßüí¶ Smaller droplets can travel up to 8Ô∏è‚É£ metres.  by sneezing and coughing into a tissue or the inside of your arm. If you use a tissue, wash your hands or use sanitiser after.

Reminder: Avoid touching your face if you haven‚Äôt washed your hands first. When you touch your face with dirty hands, germs can enter your body through your eyes, nose and mouth, and make you unwell.

A study by the  found only 76% of men always wash their hands after going to the toilet, and 59% wash their hands before touching food. Washing your hands regularly can help to reduce your risk of getting sick or passing infections on to others.

Covering your coughs and sneezes in a tissue or your elbow helps to stop the spread of viruses. If you use a tissue, put it in the bin and wash your hands after. Turn away from other people when you cough or sneeze too.

COVID-19 is easily spread via tiny air droplets from sneezing and coughing.ü§ßüí¶ Smaller droplets can travel up to 8Ô∏è‚É£ metres.  by sneezing and coughing into a tissue or the inside of your arm. If you use a tissue, wash your hands or use sanitiser after.

A study by the  found only 76% of men always wash their hands after going to the toilet, and 59% wash their hands before touching food. Washing your hands regularly can help to reduce your risk of getting sick or passing infections on to others.

Covering your coughs and sneezes in a tissue or your elbow helps to stop the spread of viruses. If you use a tissue, put it in the bin and wash your hands after. Turn away from other people when you cough or sneeze too.

COVID-19 is easily spread via tiny air droplets from sneezing and coughing.ü§ßüí¶ Smaller droplets can travel up to 8Ô∏è‚É£ metres.  by sneezing and coughing into a tissue or the inside of your arm. If you use a tissue, wash your hands or use sanitiser after.

A study by the  found only 76% of men always wash their hands after going to the toilet, and 59% wash their hands before touching food. Washing your hands regularly can help to reduce your risk of getting sick or passing infections on to others.

Covering your coughs and sneezes in a tissue or your elbow helps to stop the spread of viruses. If you use a tissue, put it in the bin and wash your hands after. Turn away from other people when you cough or sneeze too.
